reviewText:
1 year update - I use these way more than I ever thought I would. I sweat in them on long runs, I wear them driving to talk (one ear only, obviously), and I wear them around the house listening to podcasts. They have never failed to pair, they have never sounded bad.

My only dislike is that they bounce around if you run with them. In winter (now) I tuck them under my jacket, but in summer they bounce and are annoying, but still usable. In summer I use 2 large safety pins to secure the ends to my shirt to keep them from moving around on my neck.

And once I had to clear the memory (read how online at moto website).this was when I'd upgraded to a new phone and had too many devices paired, I think.

1 month Update: I've been asked how they hold up with sweat (see below). No problem working up a sweat on the treadmill, but I must stress that I've not put in a summer run. I also must say that I do not expect longevity from a non-sweatoroof product, and that the s11 headphones are designed with a sweatproof nano coating. HOWEVER, since you asked, they still sound and work excellent. They bounce around running, but it's not intolerable... Just not ideal. BATTERY: I've used them every day since I got them, and often times days at the house studying all day and going to the gym. They last from morning to night constantly connected. I often forget I'm wearing them when I turn on my music and don't hear any sound from my phone/tablet.

Edit: just for the record, the Motorola site says these are NOT for working out (under questions about product, it says not sweatproof and should be kept away from moisture). I'm going to work out in them anyway and I'll report back when they fail.
=============================================================

I bought the jaybird bluebuds x for my girlfriend, and I've used them several times, so that is my comparison point.

These headphones have a very utilitarian, price conscious design. They don't sound as awesome as the $180 bluebuds, and they aren't as sleek as them (bluebuds are just a cord with tiny ear pieces). BUT, they are very easy to control, very light, and sound very good. I'm not taking away anything by saying they don't sound as good as the bluebuds... The bluebuds sound as good as Bose or klipsch wired models of similar cost (even MKBHD says they are amazing). The Motorola buds really sound great. I'd choose them based on sound over any of the cheaper wired sets I have (skull candy, JVC, etc.)

The ear pieces, at first, I was worried about them. They didn't look like they would be very secure, but I was wrong. You can easily work out with them and they will stay in. And they swivel a bit at the ear pieces, so every time you move, you don't hear a bunch of thumping like many in-ear wired sets.

And taking them out to hear the world around you is nice, because of the magnets. No flopping around.

The built-in equalizer settings are nice, the controls are easy, and they stay around your neck when laying on your back.

So you sacrifice some portability over the bluebuds, but you get a great ease of use, very good sound, and less than half the price.

And truthfully, while they aren't super stylish... People are walking around with those giant beats studio headphones on. These look way less ridiculous than that, and really aren't that bad. Don't wear them to a job interview.

These are great headphones.  I use them for podcasts primarily.  The quality is decent.  They are not great with music but I don't use them for that.  These have a great design allowing me to lean back and relax without bumping them out of place.

I switched to these Motorola Buds after several pairs of LG Tones (730, 750, 800). Price wise these Buds are a much better value compared to the mid level LG units, but they aren't great. Volume is on the weak side, absolutely no idea of remaining battery life, until only about 10 minutes left. Connectivity is much better than LG, which was awful. Fit was OK. Magnets could be stronger. Overall they are fairly mediocre, but you easily get what you pay for.

I used these for one year, before switching over to the Samsung Level U Pro, which is a HUGE upgrade for only a few dollars more.

I have had a pair for a couple years now and love them. Grammy was so unhappy with the ear buds she had I surprised her with her own pair and she loves them just as much. Now I can talk to her without having to ask her to repeat herself a hundred times.
summary: Second pair we have purchased, love them!

Another maddening problem with the Buds is no fast forward or rewind. I didn't think to even look for this feature, I assumed no one would make a headset without it. Turns out they do. DEVICE ONE CONNECTED!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  literally blasting in my ears when i turn them on and forget that the buds are still in my ears. No way to adjust that and it appears they want to be sure deaf people know the headset is active. Loud beeps when you adjust the volume, too.

Im actually glad they're dead because now I can replace them with a proper set and I was too cheap to do it while they still worked. Good riddance.

reviewText: Great sound quality, nice fit, and easy controls. Super easy Bluetooth connection. Would definitely recommend.
fits an sounds very clear

I always care most about sound quality and signature of a Bluetooth earbuds or headphones.
for me, that is the most important aspect of "good BT headphone."

As far as sound quality and signature are concerned, this Motorola SF500 is one of the best in the class.  Specially, for the money I paid for ($19 with Lightening deal), it is an awesome BT headphone.  Very refined clear mid and high with decent, tight bass which is not very common at this price range.  Also when I check the built quality, it is solidly built and designed.  I should say that it can be compared to more expensive models of LG or Samsung BT headphones (but I like SF500 Sound quality much more).

Even though I like the sound quality very much, I wish that the volume level could be bit louder.  When I compared to other similar price range BT headphones, such as SoundPEATS QY7 or Mpow, the volume isn't quite loud enough.  It could go up one or two notch louder...
Also unlike Samsung, LG and even Mpow, SF500 has very ridge body that you can not really bend as you like. For me, it fits me well enough since I have a normal size neck, but I can see that if someone with fatter or bigger neck, it might not fit comfortably due to its stiffness in the body of headphone.  Also, it has 3 EQ settings.  Personally I like the second one the most which brings out clear mid and high.  It is a good feature to have.

There are couple of black rubber rings to keep the wires and adjust the length of the earbud wires.  it is just a couple of flimsy rubber bands that could be broken in a week or two.  I hope that they had used something stronger plastic type rather than cheap & weak black rubber band.
also, as you can see in the photos, the earbuds will be attached to the tips of the headphone by magnets.  The magnets are rather strong and they get attached well enough, but it seemed to me that how they made it was some sort of after thought.  Basically, it does not look good nor functionally well designed.  I rather prefer to see Samsung or LG type of more hidden and secure looking attachments.

Finally, the earbuds are very small. Entire earbud structures and design are very small. Even the rubber earbuds that comes with 3 different sizes are smaller and flatter designed than other 99% of earbuds.  I think when I use the biggest earbuds, it works well enough and I get adequate seals when I listen to music.  But I just feel that they might slip off when I am running or doing some activities.

Motorola SF500 is well made.  Good sounding and solid structure. However, there are many things to be improved. Small things.
summary: Great sound quality and solidly built headphone with some minor design flaws.

reviewText: My second pair. First pair lasted 14 months of hard use. Probably got really wet and that caused them to fail. Excellent product and price. After using these can't imagine ever going back to wired headphones again. Also great for answering calls. Only minor complaint would be the volume could go louder but it's just about perfect.

If you have a 17 inch neck like I do, this will not give, it will be tight around the neck and uncomfortable.. Sound is good and everything else is great, but I don't like feeling like I am being choked.

These arrived very fast and came well packaged.  I am comparing these against three versions of LG Tones that I have owned (the 750,810, and 900s) While I like the Tones but they have a bad habit of giving out within a year (the 900s lasted about 14 months) and are much more expensive. So I thought I'd give these a try.

Love them. Great sound once I got the right earpieces on. Seems to be a quality build and being Motorola should last as long at least as the Tones. Controls were a little confusing at first (I hung up on one call trying to adjust the volume) but you will get used to it. Tone control is OK but not as responsive as the tones.
The only gripe here is that the call/answer button is the same button that activates the music player and changes tone. Too many functions for one button. So when I go to place a call if I hold it down to short it instead begins to play music or too long it changes tone. I'm sure I'll get used to that too but for now because of this I deducted a star. You may feel different about the ergonomics because overall I am pleased.

I bought this for my husband and we were super excited to use it. He used them at work but had the ear piece fall off several times while working. He does work a lot with moving boxes and stuff so maybe it's more suitable for using in the car or jogging. The other issue we found with this was that we tried connecting more than one phone to it but it would only recognize one of them. I'm not sure if there was something we were doing wrong but we tried the same process for the second phone as the first and we just couldn't seem to get it to connect to the second one. He hasn't been able to use it for a while because the earphone piece fell off again and got lost so now we need to replace that. I don't think this is a good product for him to use while working, but like I said, I think it is good for casual use.
summary: I bought this for my husband and we were super excited to use it

reviewText:
This is my first review of a product. Anyway, here we go.

Saw a flash sale for some Motorola SF500 Earbuds from Dailysteals.com. My last pair of earbuds stopped powering on. So, I jumped on these for the cheap price. Got these in two days with regular postal shipping.

No pics of the box they came in. I'm guessing these are either returned or refurbished. Everything was in labeled plastic bags.

I received the earbuds, 3 set of ear tips, 1 charger with 2 ports,  USB cable, and a bag.

When looking at the picture, on the left side, the bottom lowers and top button raises the volume. On the right side, the bottom button is play/pause. The top button forwards to the next song.

The headset paired easily to my HTC M8. The phone found the headset right way and paired.

The earpiece cables have rubber bands around them to keep them close to the headset. Its up to you if you want them on or not. Right now, I have them on.

Played some Logic from Play Music and bass is decent. A little too much treble for me but I'll live with it. The headset sounds good when both ear pieces are in your ears.

The magnets that connect the earpieces to the headset is really good. They have not fallen once so far.

I'm enjoying this headset so far. The accessibility and ease are outstanding. The headset feels light around my neck.

I have no comparisons for these. These are my first pair of this type of headset. When this style first came out,  It wasn't on my radar to purchase some. I'm glad I did now. What took me so long?

I'm no audiophile but I would refer someone to these.  They come in black or white.

I have not made any phone calls yet.

Thanks for reading my first product review. Hope to do many more.

#reviewlife  #mizfits  #motorola  #sf500
summary: The headset paired easily to my HTC M8

reviewText: Sound quality could be better but still a decent headset.

reviewText: First of all, I feel a bit silly for only giving these 2 stars considering the price.  Seriously, what can you expect for less than $30?  However, just to let y'all know, I was still shocked to see just how cheap these felt in my hand after opening the package.  I understand the material they are made of keep them light, but they feel SOOO incredibly cheap.  Also, the sound is crazy bad.  You can get the same quality sound out of one of the "no name" brands available

It's not my favorite they work well ***** BUT no vibration and what's up with the small ear bud cords ??? You have to look forward when talking no room to move your head left or right also I wish it was all black in color.

Great little set of headphones. I got these for my dad to take along for his walks so he can easily answer the phone, and also not have to worry about misplacing the headphones. They fit him great, but I definitely won't be getting a pair for myself as they are a tad too tight around the sides. The bass is very weak, but that isn't a problem with the music he likes to listen to, but the overall sound is great for oldies, adult contemporary, jazz, blues, etc. The volume is definitely high enough for spoken word as well.

They came with three different sized buds, but the ones they came with worked fine. They also have a small rubber band around the wires that the buds are connected to, which works well to adjust the length you need. The back of the buds is magnetic and attaches to the front. Has about a 15 foot distance where the bluetooth is reliable and doesn't start cutting out.
summary: Great if you don't listen to bassy music and have a thin neck.

reviewText: I personally like these headphones for their sound, function and value, though they are not sweat proof (my QY8 are so far.)  I want to try Motorola's newer model soon as they do appear more stylish.

reviewText: I purchased these primarily for use for phone conversations and they work well for this purpose. They are comfortable on your neck. You'll forget that you even have them on. The sound quality is good for conversations and they fit well in your ear. I have had no problems with them wanting to fall out. The only 'real' issue i have is that they don't produce quality sound for listening to music. They tend to sound very tinny when listening to music. I guess i'll have to go back to my headphones for music and just use the Buds for telephone use.

reviewText: the left earbud shorted out after about 3 months. i won't be buying them again.
Light weigth and good sound plus 10 hours of playing music time

I've enjoyed these for well over a year with frequent use, including working out but mostly just around.  They are very convenient for switching between music, phone, or nothing (i.e., life).  The sound is good.  The controls are convenient and take only a little getting used to, as is the case for all such headsets.  My pet peeve is at start-up, when a voice that is way too loud and distorted states that the "device" is on and...paired.  It is especially bizarre because these otherwise never distort either voice or music. Fix: I simply keep the buds out of my ear until that awful announcement is over, then plug in.

Unfortunately, my buds just broke (volume in one ear dropped).  I looked around for alternatives but nothing looks that great (I have used similar Moto and LG earbud headsets).  And at this price, I am happy to buy again.
summary: Excellent, maybe the best available, bargain!

reviewText:
Short review: Right earbud keeps dying. Appears to be broken wires from moving. However, Moto support is great and I willingly bought a third pair (second being the free replacement of initial pair) after my warranty ran out.

Longer review:
I listen to loads of audiobooks. Easily eight hours a day, as I do chores and such. If my husband is out of town and I keep listening into the night, I can hit, like, fifteen hours of audio in a day. So I needed some headphones that weren't going to die on me within a month, like all the $10 pairs I'd kept compromising on.

For Hannukah 2014, my husband got me a pair of Motorola Buds, and I instantly fell in love. Never again were my earbuds yanked from my ears as the cord twisted, and the bluetooth was strong enough that I could have my phone charge centrally in my house and be able to walk about without losing reception. Not being an audio snob, I also found the sound quality for music to be fine. The battery life was just about right, though my headphones did die on me about once or twice a month, but, again, at least eight hours continuous use.

However, as I said above, the right earbud keeps dying. It crackles a bit for a day or two, and then it's more like silence with a little crackling in every so often. My first pair of Buds started failing on June 10th, 2015, based on my e-mails (and I got the gift in mid-December). Luckily, Motorola has always been great about replacements for me (I also had a Moto X, which I broke...twice...). I was able to show my Amazon receipt and get a replacement in within a week, with Motorola paying shipping all ways.

But, today, January 4th, and JUST out of the one year warranty, my second pair of buds has died again. I checked Amazon, to see if any other products might compare, but everything I saw looked like small, shady companies with really, really bad grammar in their text. And the reviews...generally did not seem like real reviews, so much as paid reviews.

So I bought another pair, and I'm okay with that, because I LOVE THESE THINGS! $30 a year for exactly what I want in headphones is fine with me!

Now, granted, when this next warranty runs out? I'm hoping there will be other items on the market to try which might not need replacing halfway through their minimum lifecycle. But, for now, with Motorola treating me so well, I'm willing to keep going.
summary: I'm averaging 6-month life as an 8-hour-a-day user

reviewText: I actually bought three of us this year for family and friends and I have one for myself so I guess that's 4. These are great your buds for the price fantastic
summary: These are great your buds for the price

reviewText: the magnets on the back of one of the earbuds came off

I used these every single day at my desk, and the charge generally lasts the full work day.  Comfortable, functional and now I can't live without them.  I do think that the microphone is a bit sensitive to movement on your shirt or collar which can create a loud sound for your caller on the other end (so I try to remain still while on a call) but the stereo sound is good and the Bluetooth connection has never dropped from my phone once.  I like the ability to answer calls, skip tracks and control volume from the device.  They are light, and more than once I've left the house forgetting I'm wearing them.  Love these at work and while walking for exercise.  Cannot comment on their water resistance, as I don't use in the rain or sweat profusely while exercising -- but for my daily needs, these are great for taking tunes and talk radio wherever I go (housework, workplace, shopping at the store to relieve boredom, etc).  Had them for over a year and battery still going strong.
summary: Fantastic, comfortable, functional headphones.  Microphone for calls not perfect -- but still Five Stars

The on/off switch can be accidentally pressed if wearing collared shirts. Poor microphone quality. Switched back to LG.
These are great and worth the price. I use them just walking around the house and haven't used them while working out yet. I'm hoping they hold up for a while.

Excellent sound for the price. Much higher volume than similar SoundPeats headset. Bought SoundPeats headset and Cosmos travel case. The Motorola Buds are longer and too large for Cosmos case. Anybody with Buds found a travel case that they will fit in????
love the sound quality of music.  sometimes people have a hard time hearing me - maybe the microphone could be improved?

Wasn't sure what to expect from these. They're the first pair of BT headphones I've purchased that have the battery resting on my neck. But, man, these are terrific! They last for 2-3hrs of actual playback and the neck piece is actually so light that you forget it is there. The small strings on the earbuds allow my head to turn easily without any pulling whatsoever. Very quick charging time, too.

Saw the "beefier" versions in the local cellular stores, but at a much higher price. Figured I'd stick my toe in with the low-cost model and am not disappointed. I'll buy the better model if these ever wear out - I know I'll be getting my money's worth.

I quite like these. After trying a number of cheaply made Chinese Bluetooth headphones, all of which failed within a month or two, I tried a name brand. Go figure, they work well and thus far haven't failed me. They sound fine. The buds fit in my ear. The charge lasts around 8 hours.

So, they work as they should, and they haven't died as quickly as the horrible Chinese junk.  Look elsewhere (at audiophile prices) if you crave audiophile headphones.  These are workman headphones.

The one thing to consider is whether they will fit on your neck. They are made of a rigid plastic, so that if you have a large neck, they won't fit at all.

I ever that I was not paid to provide a rave review with cash, prizes, or merchandise. I bought these with my own money for my personal use.  The fake reviews that permeate the ethically challenged people who post electronic junk reviews is making it difficult to trust any reviews posted on Amazon, which does mean that the rest of us need to post honest reviews.

I love the in the ear buds, but I'm not thrilled with how easily they turn off. It doesn't take make pressure if I have them on and lay down to rest. I haven't been happy with them soon aftyet I received them. I don't like the feel of them around my neck. It is a ok product, it just doesn't work for me. I do love the fit in the ear and the sound quality is good for what j use mine for.

Picked these up refurb'd on another site for 20 bucks.  Having owned both the Motorola S9 and S10, I wasn't expecting much.  The S10 was a downgrade in sound quality from the older S9's (which had WOW EQ...the S10s had no EQ settings at all), so why would these be any better?  Man was I wrong.  I would imagine much of this is owed to the aptX codec that is supported by my Note 4 and the fact that they have brought back built-in EQ settings.  With my S10s I needed to use a phone EQ to make them sound even mediocre.  Not these.  I turned my EQ off and use the built-in and they sound amazing.

Another huge thing that has been upgraded is comfort.  Due to the odd shape and size of the earbuds on the S9s and S10s, if you wore them for more than an hour or so they became extremely uncomfortable.  These have moved to a more traditional earbud format, not to mention you don't look like the guy from Star Wars with some stupid blinking band wrapped around the back of your head, its a simple band looped around your neck with ample cord length for the buds.

Overall, much improved over Moto's previous efforts, and a fantastic bargain, even at the full retail price, considering I paid over $50 for both my S9s and S10s.  Good on you Motorola!  Great product!
summary: Great Update over the older S9 and S10

reviewText: Love it and great price too!

I've owned 4 pairs of LG Tones, and was hoping these would be a competitor. If sound quality doesn't matter to you, these are good headphones.

Pros:
* Good BT range.
* Thats pretty much it.

Cons:
* Lifeless unrealistic sound. There's too much bass, too little kids, and the high's are abhorrent-- they sounds like you're in a cave. You can heard a lot of quantization errors in the signal, it would not surprise me to learn the signal is being decimated or the digital filters are designed incorrectly or absent. It sounds a lot like my first CD plated in the last 80s.
summary: If you care about sound quality move on.

reviewText: So far 5 star's

Wasn't sure if these would meet my goals but they come 90% to what I'd hoped for. They are comfortable to wear, the cords haven't caught on anything yet (like ipod buds will) and once I got the right size ends they sealed out the outside sound to a large degree and gave greater volume. I have old timers tinnitus and high freq hearing loss so cannot comment on fidelity but they are quite good for me.

buds are small enough and fit well into my hear holes that I can get my motorcycle helmet on and off with these in place without disturbing them! They aren't overly loud but loud enough to allow me to hear pavement engine and some traffic noise with the music turned up. Controls are easy for non-throttle hand to find and use once I figured out which button does what. Paired with my iPhone 6 quickly, and the only lack is a 'back' button to replay a song if you would want or a skip forward and back a bit to rehear an audiobook passage.

I've already recommended these to others so I guess I like them that well and at $35 they're a steal!
summary: Got these for motorcycling and am not disappointed.

reviewText: Absolutely excellent!  Has made using my phone so much more pleasurable!  Easy to connect and battery lasts a long time!  Were delivered ahead of time in great packaging!  Would buy again!

THEY ARE DEAD! I got these on Sunday 8/9/15... They worked. Sound wonderful. No choppy reseption even 40+ feet away!. Used them at work... And they did the job. I was pleased with them up to this point. Today, went to the gym and they worked wonderful. Get done with a 30 min run and they are now dead!
The buds work really well and I love the convenience. The sound quality is great for talking but average for music.

The two biggest drawbacks are the fact that the wires attached to the earbuds get in the way (they need to produce a retractable model), and Motorola does not sell replaceable cushions for the buds.  I lost one that fit my ear and had to settle for a larger one that kept falling out because I couldn't find replacements anywhere.  The range on this thing is amazing, however, and they are lightweight and sound great.  I am moving on to another Motorola device however because of the aforementioned reasons.  The price has dropped on all of them and I can get a better set for less than I originally paid for these.  Also, I tried my wife's LG set....I liked the vibration feature, but the range is MUCH shorter than the Motorola brands.
summary: Nice, but Motorola needs to sell replacement bud cushions...

reviewText: MY HUSBAND LOVE THIS BECAUSE IT IS JUST LIKE HIS FIRST ONE HE HAD.

First of all, I just got these so I can't speak to the longevity.  I've been using a $12 set of buds for almost a year and have put up with the hassle of the wires just because they sound so flippin good.  With a frequency response of 10 to 20,000Hz, I got all the bass I wanted as well as mid to high range.  That said, I was leery about BT ear buds but I've always been a fan of Moto products even though I have a Samsung Avant phone so I decided to give them a try.

I got the buds yesterday, charged them up and tried them out.  I placed them on my neck and they curved down and rested on my collar bone very comfortably.  I turned them on with the button which is located in the back; kind of awkward but not a deal breaker.  Pairing them with my Samsung  Avant phone was very quick and easy; the Avant recognized them immediately and all I had to do was confirm the pairing. The first thing I noticed was that the sound wasn't as rich or deep as I had hoped.  The buds felt like they wanted to pull out because the connecting wires seemed to stretch to their limits as I turned my head and I don't have a big neck and, even though I have been accused of having a big head, it is actually quite average.  I had read about this being an issue from another reviewer so I moved the adjustment bands all the way back to give me as much wire as possible and that helped but anything rubbing against them, like a shirt collar, might be a hindrance, plus, I was still bothered about the sound.

I started playing with the buttons after reading the directions in the instruction manual and found they were reversed from my buds.  It showed the volume on the on the left side but when I pushed the left front button, I got the EQ.  Rotating through the EQ's didn't seem to make much difference.  The volume adjustment was actually on the right side and the call/play and track buttons are on the left side.  Once I got that figured out, I was ok.  Also, if you have a smart watch, you might not even have to worry about the controls.  I have a Moto360 and it also pairs to the phone at the same time as the buds so that just a plus for me.

Back to the buds.  Because the buds come with the smallest ear pieces installed, I thought it might help to use the medium buds so I switched them for the small ones and they helped with the problem of them staying in my ears but didn't really improve the sound.  (By the way, they fit on the headset pretty snuggly so I don't think they will likely fall off and get lost.) While wearing them today, I found that the sound was okay with voices like comedy routines and wasn't too bad for normal music but I wanted more base.  I discovered that if I cupped my hands over my ears that I could hear the deeper base of the techno music I was listening to ... but I looked like an idiot so that wasn't a solution.  I was actually ready to send them back for a refund but when I got home I decided to try one more thing.  If I was covering the buds with my hands and they sounded better, maybe sound was "leaking out" so I tried the larger ear pieces.  In all honesty, that sounds like a stupid explanation but the bigger ear pieces do give me more base ... not nose bleed bass but adequate.  So, I listened to Southern rock to Techno to Classical and they all sound great to these aging ears so now I'll just have to see how the battery life is.

As for the Bluetooth, now that I have them paired, they hook up almost instantly.  I can't use them in the car because I have a BT transmitter for the stereo and they conflict with each other but other than that, I can roam around without dropping the BT on the earbuds.  By the way, I also noticed a difference in the EQ by switching ear pieces, albeit ever so slight.  One setting sounds like it has less bass, one with a little more and one with almost a slight bassy echo.

So, for me, the only cons (kind of) right now are:
  - Power button is in the back behind your neck so are not real convenient.
  - Status light is in the back behind your neck (not a problem if you have eyes in the back of your head).
  - Connecting wires for the buds could be a tad longer.
  - Sound could be fuller but probably decent for this price point.
but none of these are a real reason to deduct a star
summary: Could be better but very nice at this price point

reviewText:
Great price on these headphones. I use them to garden/work in the yard so I can wear a hat and still have good ear protection from the noise of my small engines. I can answer calls, play/pause music, control volume etc... It's best feature as advertised is the RANGE. I get really good range for this device. I'm not realizing the 150 ft advertised distance but I am getting way further than I ever have with other bluetooth devices. Keep in mind that getting the maximum range is line of sight but I have kept my connected phone in the house and the headphones on outside without a problem.
Battery life is great and pairing to any device has also been great. I've paired with Android and iOS devices without any issues.
Two things to be aware of: 1) this is not a waterproof/sweatproof device. I have sweat a lot on mine without a problem, but I've heard other people complain about that. I just clean mine off after having it on my collar and it's good to go. 2) The volume buttons on the headphones control just the headphones, they do not control volume on the phone/ipod/ipad you are connected to.

This is my third purchase. The second headset purchase failed to turn on after the first 4 weeks of use. My first Motorola Buds headset lasted me a year of daily use bicycling plus jogging a few days a week. The first set was durable, sweat resistant, has excellent controls for: google now, skipping tracks, volume control. Bluetooth pairing could sometimes be finicky, but the range is good. They are light and molded to not fall of the neck with movement like running or sit ups.
Hell yeah

The sound is really good considering these aren't super pricey earbuds. They are fairly comfortable to wear throughout the day. I have not tried to wear them while working out or running / jogging yet but it seems like they'd feel ok. Battery life has been good. I charged them the first day I got them and have used them for about 6-7 hours over the past week for calls and music and haven't had to charge them yet. They are a little awkward to store away in my backpack or purse as the main piece that sits around your neck is a little bit stiff. I feel afraid of breaking them if I just toss them in my backpack with all my other junk. So far, no breaking though. They seem sturdy.
cheap, light but a little bit tight around the neck

The quality seems up to Motorola's standards but the volume isn't loud enough when listening to music or when having a conversation.  Also, if you have a medium or larger sized neck, the neck band will squeeze against the sides of your neck.  The controls work well and the magnets that hold the buds to the neck band when not in use are pretty strong.  As long as you won't be driving or anywhere loud, these will probably work pretty well for you and the price is good.

The only real drawback for me was that the buds are a bit short from neck to ear, and tend to pull a little when I turn my head too far in either direction. I'm not a giraffe, but I do have a long neck! This should have been taken into consideration though. In terms of operation, the sound (as Larry David would say) is "prittttttty, prittttttttty good!" It's not BOSE, but it's good enough for the price. Additionally, for phone calls (which is really why I bought this) it's great. I've had no problems with people hearing me, nor from me hearing them. Definitely a good buy (not a GOOD BYE!)

The sound is tinny and doesn't seem loud enough even with the headset and phone both on max volume. I drive a truck for a living and don't really think I will be able to hear adequately with these in a working environment. Even if they were loud enough the sound is still tinny and low quality.
summary: The sound is tinny and doesn't seem loud enough even ...

reviewText:
Pros:
- Consistently excellent battery life. Always ready to go when you are.
- Lightweight and comfortable around the neck. You forget they're even there.
- Microphone is excellent, clear, loud, and crisp.
- Price! These are half the price of your Sony SBH or your LG Tones, and the battery life is better as a trade off for sound quality and style.

Cons:
- Earbud cables are a bit constraining if you have a long neck. They sometimes pop out of the ear when you turn your head suddenly.
- Music quality is not the greatest, but will do in a pinch.
- First pair I ordered had a defective left ear bud. Amazon to the rescue there. Quick and painless RMA and the next set were perfect.

To Buy or Not to Buy:
- If you want style and rich quality sound for music and media playback, look elsewhere.
- If you need a go to "git 'er done" headset for calls and basic audio, and you don't want to break the bank, these are for you!

The Moto Buds are extremely lightweight and easy to pair with nearly every device that supports BlueTooth 4.0. They are comfortable in the ear for extended wear (2-4 hours), the battery life is astoundingly good, and they sleep without draining battery better than the LG Tones or the Sony SBH series.

But every rose has its thorns, and alas the Moto Buds are not without their flaws. The first is these danged ear bud cables. Someone in accounting figured out the average neck length and forced the designers to shorten these things to exactly that length and no longer. As a person of above average height, this poses a problem for me, as the cables stay nearly taut all the time, even when I'm looking straight ahead. Turn your head to the left or right and at best you're going to loosen one bud, or completely pull it out of your ear at worst.

I've learned to forgive the Moto Buds for this over time because whenever I need them, they work perfectly. I regularly pair them with a laptop, tablet, and phone, and switching between those devices is remarkably simple and straight forward. Oh, and they're less than half the price of the competition. Let's not forget that!

Sound quality is adequate, but basses are not as deep, and highs are not as clear as other, more music-focused headsets. These are your go-to utilitarian communication earbuds, that will also let you listen to Taylor Swift on your coffee break. She just won't sound as good.

The controls for music and volume are a tad awkwardly placed, and learning how to use the textured skip button as the pause/play button also is a little tricky, but once you've learned it, you've mastered it.

Moto would do well to increase the earbud cable length, even if only by 5 centimeters, to allow the wearer more freedom of movement. However, if you'll be wearing these while sitting at your desk or driving in your car most of the time, you'll have no trouble at all, especially if you are of average height or less.
summary: The Moto Buds are your bud!

reviewText: outstanding
One of the best headsets i ever brought
Great headset!

Simple, no frills, and the quality is bad.  I use Bluetooth headphones for my workouts. The audio breaks up a lot and every phone call I've taken on these... It drops the call after 30 seconds of any conversation.

I found a pair of Bluetooth headphones an amazon for $20 that came from china and took a month to arrive... But they work 100 times better than my Motorola's. I'd pass on this product.
Okay - not easy to wear, for me, and after the first use, did not ever recharge again.  Tossed them - there is NO musical usefulness with these - to my ears anyway.

I have owned these headphones for over a year now.  I can say that they are pretty solid performers.  I use them fairly regularly, probably about 15-20 hours a week, and have both used them connected to my laptop and to my Nexus 5.

PROS:

Battery Life: is very good.  I can usually use them for a day and a half before they need to be charged again, and charging typically takes about 2 hours I would guess.

Sound: is decent provided you have the proper sized ear gels, (more on this later).
Comfort: Weight and flat wires are nice, with the "brains" of the unit being at the rear, it balances this device out a bit.

Longevity: My warranty is now expired, and I never had to use it.  Owned for 14 months and no issues with my pair.

CONS and Caveats:

Range: I haven't had big problems with wandering away from my phone, but they definitely don't really have a "half-football-field" range as advertised.  I imagine if you were walking away from your phone on a football field, you could get up to 50 yards away, but the 150 foot advertised range is obviously with no interference.  I can get across my office building though before they start to lose signal, but the signal loss is worse if I say, turn around (with my head/neck directly between the phone and the receiver) I probably lose 15-20 feet of range.

EQ: the three EQ settings are pointless, I can hear almost no difference between them, and the "EQ changed" voice is not particularly helpful.  I wish it would say "flat" or "bass boost" for whatever setting it gets switched to.

Long winded power on: This is a pretty silly preference, but they are long in the tooth when turned on.  Sometimes if I'm in mid call and turn these on, I want to connect right away, but I have to wait for (and read this out loud so you can see how long it takes), "(Bingy sound effect that plays for about 1 second) Welcome to the Motorola Buds.  Device one connected."  This power on cycle takes roughly six seconds, during which phone audio cannot be heard.

Ear gels (IMPORTANT): This is probably going to be the biggest factor as to whether you are satisfied with these or not.  These headphones will be nowhere near loud enough and have terrible bass response if you do not have the best fit for your ear to create the "seal" between the driver (or speaker) and your ear canal.  I have a good fit and sound in my left ear, but none of the three included sizes seem to work well with my right ear.  If I'm wearing both, it doesn't bother me too much, and I very frequently only have one in when I'm at work so I can still hear people talk to me if I'm needed.  Right ear alone, however, is not an option for me.  If you ever lose or replace your ear-tips/gels, replacements are simply "unavailable" per Motorola.  I still have all mine, but Motorola tells me, if you lose them or they become damaged, Motorola just replaces the entire headset, (really, Motorola?)
summary: After a year, Solid, but not for everyone.

reviewText:
I shopped and shopped. Researched and the opinions all said this is such a good unit.

My experience is dramatically different. Folks on the other end of the connection complain about the noise and poor voice quality EVERY SINGLE TIME. It is not useable. Very disappointed. Expected that my audio quality would be good and would be fun to use to listen to music. WRONG. What I heard was low volume and low fidelity. Not good for listening to music.

reviewText:
Overall, these are merely OK. I primarily use these while commuting, so a mix of walking on city streets, subways, and the bus. I have three issues with the Motorola Buds -- 1) sound quality, 2) fit and length of cable, and 3) some weird bluetooth connection issues.

SOUND QUALITY: These are OK. In terms of sound, I think the Sony MW600 with stock earbuds have better sound. These are ok, but the bass is a bit muddy and the treble is a bit recessed. Volume is good. Phone quality is OK -- the other side reports sounding like I'm on a speakerphone.

FIT AND CABLE LENGTH: Perhaps my body is shaped weird, but I think the earbuds are a little too short -- again, the stock earbuds with the Sony MW600 fit my ears better. I struggle to find a good seal, and when I do, just opening my mouth or turning my head is enough to loosen them. I've tried all three earpiece sizes, and the best fitting one is the medium one. As others have noted, due to the slightly smaller than normal earbuds, most other earpieces won't fit this one. The cable length could use another half inch -- while walking around, looking while crossing the street causes the cable to tug at my ears.

BLUETOOTH CONNECTION: Range is OK -- I can make it maybe 30 feet in my apartment. However, my biggest problem is that, during times of silence (say when switching tracks), the Motorola Buds will emit a short "pop" sound, and then it'll skip maybe 100 ms at the beginning of a song. I'm using an iPhone 5 with iOS 8.3. This is a bit annoying, and I can live with it, but this wasn't a problem with the Sony MW600.

As an aside, I purchased mine through Verizon, so I'm pretty sure mine is an original and not a counterfeit.

Otherwise, it looks nice, the buttons have a nice tactile feel, and it looks nice. It works OK with the iPhone (there's no battery indicator though). It's OK, but I prefer the sound of my Sony MW600 earbuds.
summary: Merely OK, probably better options in the price range

I don't know what Motorola was thinking, but they could have a done a much better job on the sound coming from the headphones. If you look at the ear tips, you can see how tiny it is. I cranked this bad boy up and you can hear the bass seemed liked it wanted to come out but seemed restricted. I was disappointed until a coworker of mine told me that to improve the bass, you need the change the ear tips to ones where the canals have a larger diameter. If you have the headphones that come with the samsung galaxy phones or jax or motorola tracks in-ear headphones, swap those ear piece tips with these. When I did, OMG you could now hear the bass thumping away. Looking at some of Motorola's headphones, why couldn't the engineers figure this out? Really Motorola?
Also make sure that you read the user manual to adjust the built-in EQ by cycling through the modes and select the one with bass. It sounds excellent now, and hope others would change the tips to a larger canal to improve their experience.

reviewText:
I first purchased and then returned the LG Tone+ headset which had issues working properly with my Samsung Galaxy Note 2. (Bluetooth would cut out and lock up my home screen when I carried phone in back pocket. Other times it would behave ok.  Also, the Tone would not work with out going calls--I could hear the other person, but they could not hear me.) I've read about others having this same problem, even with other brand phones. And plusses of the LG over the Motorola were not worth the hassle of trying to figure out of this could be remedied. In fact, others I read about could not find a fix for the problem.

I realize that Motorola Buds may not have all the features that the Tone+ has, but they pair and play perfectly with my phone.  They feel DIFFERENT than tone+ around the neck and in the ears, and music sounds slightly DIFFERENT; different isn't better or worse. I do find the earbud cords somewhat too short if I don't carefully roll the little rubber bands up towards the top of the neck band which gives them more leeway. Hopefully, the bands won't break like others have complained of.

Although I did like the controls and position of the buttons on the Tone+ better, I am very happy with my Motorola Buds.  I was recently using the Buds to speak with my sister who uses the LG Tone +(and both she and her husband have developed problems with their LG headsets similar to what I experienced). She had no idea I was on a bluetooth headset during the call, it sounded that good!  She is now watching for a good deal on Motorola Buds for herself.
Absolutely love how these buds work without getting in my way or making me look like a space traveler.
summary: Reasonably discreet wireless headset that just works.
